awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Examining Community-based Recovery Initiatives Post-Disaster
awd_abstract_narration:
After a recent disaster, community-based organizations known as mutual support centers emerged to organize post-disaster response. This project seeks to examine communities' perceptions of and response to programs implemented by these centers. The project asks: How have communities responded to the emergence of these centers and their projects? What areas of community development have been affected by these implemented projects? The project is focused on communities' capacity to assess and develop solutions to their needs through self-managing community development projects. The project examines how pre-existing social inequalities, which become particularly salient after natural disasters, shape the resulting community response. Findings from this project will provide government agencies, social scientists, and communities with insights related to response and recovery processes. Such findings can assist with policy formulation at multiple levels of government to promote recovery from disasters more efficiently, thus contributing to safety and security in our society.    

Sociologists have identified emergent organizations as a common occurrence at the intersection of communities' response to uncertainty and failed communications between impacted communities and formal agencies. However, the ways in which these emergent actors are created, and their internal operationalization of response and recovery, are not well understood. Based on a purposive sampling design, the study will examine five mutual support centers working in different communities throughout the affected region. The project uses a qualitative, multi-technique approach that includes eighty  semi-structured interviews with residents of beneficiary communities where the centers have been established, two sets of focus groups with residents in each community, including forty-eight respondents, and ethnographic participant observation in center events, programs and service centers  to draw a comprehensive  perception of the organizations and programs.  After data transcription, the project will code the data using MAXQDA qualitative software by first developing analytical codes followed by lower level codes reflecting characteristics and patterns in the data.  Findings from the project will inform sociological theories regarding disaster response, emergent organizations and their communications, and social inequality following extreme events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was informed by the scholarship on the social construction of disasters that points out the capacity of natural disaster events to reveal and make evident pre-existing social inequities and precarities, suggesting that processes of recovery and reconstruction provide opportunities to remediate these issues in the future. While scholars in and outside of sociology have pointed out that community-based organizations are in a favorable position to best assess needs and coordinate the response to disaster relief very little is known about community members’ experiences with these post-disaster community organizations. In the context of Hurricane María, most assessments of community work describe projects within marginalized communities that maintain the status quo, reinforcing the argument that community responses to crises are not conducive to transformative change. Our research point at the ways communities generated programs and initiatives were able produce structural change and address key areas neglected. Our findings suggested that community initiatives sought to enact programs while promoting new practices of self-provisioning and empowerment. Though the level of success of community projects was impacted by lack of resources, external pressures, and organizer burnout, these organizations ignited individuals into community organizing among people previously unfamiliar with these practices.

The historical juncture which framed Hurricane María by the time of this study provided a rare, if not unique opportunity to examine how community-based organizations focused on self-management, developed and evolved, as well as how they interpreted and responded to pre-disaster conditions and challenges in their interventions. Most of the work on natural disasters has focused on vulnerabilities of marginalized/impoverished groups. However, to our knowledge, no scholars was examining how structural conditions of precarity in a community impinge on processes of recovery and rebuilding after a natural phenomenon. Our research documents how for little more than seven years after the hurricane, many programs are still running, most spearheading agendas of community development, that seek to create alternatives means to their precarious livelihoods and structural vulnerabilities. As participant-observers our work have provided communities with nuances on their trajectories, pitfalls and surge with the goal of supporting their social goals. Our insights and findings have been shared with community organizers as material to reflect on their programs and assess their reach and projections.

One central aspect to our project has been a serious commitment to make our research findings available to the communities we were working with. On that line, our findings have assisted community organizations through the creation of educational material that gives visibility and support to the work that these initiative have produced since 2018 (https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/3915e3b4f5954ae3b40239e5805604ab), and supported the creation of pubic advisory material on hurricane preparedness (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R25z3HJuILs).

In parallel, this project has served as an opportunity to introduce a younger generation of students at the undergraduate level to the world of research and tool them with transferable skills such as research skill development and intellectual engagement. In the period of the award, we supported two undergraduate research assistants in the home institution, State University of New York - New Paltz, through transcription skill building training, field research experience, and academic research presentations. The outcome of these efforts resulted in two weeks of field research immersion in collecting qualitative data and two academic research poster presentations at the college level and at a regional academic conference.

Lastly, in the four years of this award, our findings have appeared in peer-reviewed journals such as Centro Journal, Latino Studies and Current Sociology. We have three chapters for edited volumes coming from Duke University and AK Press. We have disseminated our work at seven academic domestic and international conferences, as well as keynotes at universities, research workshops, public forums, and online panels. At the time of this report, a book manuscript proposal on the findings of this project and its implications is under consideration by two academic presses.
